user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_unmap:
```c
void metal_dma_unmap(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg,
		  int nents)
{
	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/*If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);

	if (!dev || !dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap || !sg)
		return;
	dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg, nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_dma_unmap:
#define METAL_DMA_DEV_R 1
...
struct metal_device {
	const char             *name;       /**< Device name */
	struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
	unsigned int           num_regions; /**< Number of I/O regions in
						 device */
	struct metal_io_region regions[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS]; /**< Array of
							I/O regions in device*/
	struct metal_list      node;       /**< Node on bus' list of devices */
	int                    irq_num;    /**< Number of IRQs per device */
	void                   *irq_info;  /**< IRQ ID */
}
...
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in the provided function. Specifically:
- There are no assignments to any parameter variables (no statements like dev = ..., sg = ..., dir = ..., or nents = ...).
- The pointer parameters (dev and sg) are dereferenced (e.g., dev->bus, dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap and passed to the callee), but the pointer objects themselves are not reassigned or incremented — dereferencing or passing a pointer is allowed under MISRA Rule 17.8 (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified).
- The integer parameters (dir, nents) are only read (dir compared to METAL_DMA_DEV_R), not written.
- The call dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap(dev->bus, dev, dir, sg, nents) may allow the callee to modify the objects pointed to (permitted), but this is not a modification of the parameter variables within this function.
Therefore, there are no code fragments in this function that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and nothing to report for investigation under that rule.
